entry.title: Combined summary - RGB protocol announcement
entry.summary: The LNP/BP protocol is designed to be flexible and modular, allowing developers to build applications on top of Bitcoin's underlying technology using smart contracts that execute automatically when certain conditions are met. The LNP/BP protocol is interoperable with other blockchain projects, and the RGB Network has developed a set of standards for tokenization called the LNP/BP Standards. To support the development of the LNP/BP protocol, LNP/BP Standards Association, supported by Fulgur Ventures, Bitfinex, Hojo Foundation, Pandora Prime, and DIBA, has announced the release of RGB v0.10. This significant milestone brings full support of smart contracts to Bitcoin and Lightning after four years of extensive development work.RGB v0.10 introduces various features such as global state, contract interfaces, strict type system, Rust contracts, state introspection, URL-based invoice format, WASM support, tapret descriptors and custom derivation, simplified dependencies, integration, and UX. This version is closer to being a production-ready system, and users can download and install it from the official website of the protocol, which also contains user and developer guidelines. The LNP/BP Standards Association will focus its further development activity around completing RGB documentation, specification, helping public audits of the technology, Lightning network support for complex RGB smart contracts, and RGB toolchain, which includes a new high-level functional smart contracting language called Contractum and other tools that will simplify the life of RGB devs.Dr. Maxim Orlovsky has been working on the RGB protocol, which aims to build a programmability layer for Bitcoin and Lightning Network that enables other use cases besides tokens such as DAOs and decentralized identities. Dr. Orlovsky is also working on the design of a layer 1 that will be compact and ultra-scalable, which should be perfect for client-side-validated applications. However, there are concerns about the status of the implementations of RGB. There is minimal documentation available, and previous reviewers have been directed to watch videos or read the code.Despite four years of active development, weekly community calls, and talks at all mainstream bitcoin-only events and conferences, awareness about RGB in the bitcoin community is still very small, and the project's ambition and scope creep may be preventing it from serving its original purpose effectively. The author emphasizes the importance of proper design over shipping earlier, especially in consensus-level protocols where softforks are not possible.Dr. Orlovsky discusses the potential for a new blockchain called RGB, which would operate on both bitcoin blockchain and sigchain. RGB would allow smart contracts to function without requiring BTC/BTC* and can operate on bearer securities, bearer ownership rights, digital collateral-based stable coins, digital identity, decentralized naming systems, provable historical event logs, liquidity pools, DEXes, AMM, and other similar features on Lightning, which they call "BiFi" (Bitcoin finance). Finally, Dr. Maxim Orlovsky has released RGB v0.10, which can be downloaded and installed from their website.
